questions.question_text: While preparing for a third-party audit, the vice president of risk management and the vice president of information technology have stipulated that the vendor may not use offensive software during the audit. This is an example of:

discussion.content: not use offensive software during the audit. This is an example of: Rules of engagement
rules of engagement apply to both pentests AND audits

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a feature of virtualization that can potentially create a single point of failure?

discussion.content: C'mon, its D. Keyword is single point of failure = running multiple OS
https://community.infosecinstitute.com/discussion/65171/virtualization-and-single-points-of-failure-in-small-businesses <--- interesting discussion
Best answer is A, as consolidating lots of servers and then losing the VM is really bad, explained here: https://lenovopress.com/redp3939.pdf

This can either be A or B.
A - Server consolidation is the practice of reducing the number of servers or server locations in order to use compute resources more efficiently and reduce costs. So, if the number of server in use is reduced to 1, and all workload is given to that server, over-consolidation might be possible causing the entire server to crash, thus becoming a SPOF.
B - this article (https://www.cioreview.com/news/single-point-of-failures-in-virtual-infrastructure-and-means-to-overcome-these-nid-15223-cid-86.html) lists that load balancing can be a SPOF on a virtual environment.

questions.question_text:
A cybersecurity analyst is hired to review the security posture of a company. The cybersecurity analyst notices a very high network bandwidth consumption due to
SYN floods from a small number of IP addresses.
Which of the following would be the BEST action to take to support incident response?

choices.B: Apply ingress filters at the routers.

discussion.content: B is answer

comments.content: Router probably has FW capability or acts as one
You can filter traffic from routers, some organizations use it as their filtering, not just FW.

discussion.content: Shouldn't the filters be applied on the firewall, and not on the router itself?

Re-reading the question multiple times, i think the unidentified service points to udp/163 ,since the question mentions the use of snmp and snmptrap which uses udp/161-162. I still think its letter C.
The Answer is D. Implement SNMPv3 to secure communication. the question asking " to harden the system?" Disable unidentified services could affect the monitoring system.
The operative word here is unmanaged, this making the answer A
What the hell is the answer???
Option B: hardening the device by implementing a compensating control (segmentation and firewalling)
Horrible choices of answers. The best answer would be C 'disable unidentified service' but it doesn't specify which port is the unidentified service which should be port 163 UDP.
Unless this means SNMP is the unknown service (which is would be given the ports) in which case, yes, patch and restart. Needs to be reworded
There's no way this is A. How can you patch and restart an unknown service? If it's unknown you need to find out what it is and if it turns out to be malware you should remove it. Confusing question.
Is this really A? I'm thinking disabling the unidentified service running on port 163 would be better to implement hardening
Im leaning towards SNMPv3

choices.A: Patch and restart the unknown service.
choices.C: Disable the unidentified service on the controller.
choices.B: Segment and firewall the controller's network.

discussion.content: The question include the "policy states that all patches must undergo testing". The server here downloading the patch and deploying without testing is a clear violation of the policy and would fall under incident.

comments.content: agree with you because it should be tested before

discussion.content:
> Policy states that all patches must undergo testing procedures before being moved into production aka Business hours
> Web server has been downloading and applying patches during non-business hours without testing - This violates the policy
> Functionality wasn't interrupted by this action

This is simply a misconfiguration issue which violates the patch management policy so therefore, you create an incident ticket for anomalous activity. This will probaly involve disabling automatic updates.

C is the correct answer.

comments.content: agree but on the assumption that a misconfiguration isnt planned and the activity isnt known... this leads us to anomalous activity :)
Anomalous does not necessarily mean malicious. It could be related to configuration issues.

discussion.content: Is this already an anomalous activity? Or just a misconfigured server? Internal servers also shouldn't be downloading updates directly from the internet, and should only be getting their updates from wsus or any similar central update server.

questions.question_text:
The security configuration management policy states that all patches must undergo testing procedures before being moved into production. The security analyst notices a single web application server has been downloading and applying patches during non-business hours without testing. There are no apparent adverse reactions, server functionality does not seem to be affected, and no malware was found after a scan.
Which of the following actions should the analyst take?

choices.B: Monitor the web application service for abnormal bandwidth consumption.
choices.C: Create an incident ticket for anomalous activity.
choices.D: Monitor the web application for service interruptions caused from the patching.
choices.A: Reschedule the automated patching to occur during business hours.
